content.description:
Stand start on the lowest point of the wall. Move straight up through fantastic crimp edges, and top out left of the block at the top. 

  This had chalk on it when I found it, so I assume it has been done.
content.location: Start standing just a few feet right of the Mt. Spickett text.

content.description: This ascends an enjoyable, obvious, right-leaning crack with a couple good 2nd knuckle deep pockets as you head up. There's a good back jug at the top to finish; however, during the Fall, I'd recommend hiking up to the top and cleaning out the pine needles which can make your warm-up a little spicy. The green arrows are the standing start holds which are okay, but holds get better as you head up with decent feet for the start.
content.location: Look for the biggest tree in front of the wall and just to the right of the biggest patch of moss. I cleaned out all the moss, but bring a brush come Spring!

content.description:
Stand Start on the horizontal crack, move to a left hand pinch, and use sparse face holds to get to the jug at about 12 feet. Finish up right of the big block. 

  It seems like pretty unique rock for Lynn Woods and was dirty to the point where I thought it probably hadn't been climbed before, but please correct me if it has been.
content.protection: It has a slightly sloped landing. 1-2 pads with a spotter should suffice.
content.location: This is in the middle of the wall, about 10 feet right of the Mt. Spickett lettering. The left hand pinch is about 8 feet off the ground and should stand out.

content.description: Lay down start with a wide grip, your right hand on a big jug sticking out of the little cave, your left hand on a good sloper, and your feet deep in the underside cave. Swing your feet out to the left out of the cave, move your right hand next to the starting sloper on a not-as-good sloper, move up to a little rail and a knob at the bottom of the large crack, then climb the CRUX up to an odd, blocky, orangish part of the wall keeping your hands and feet on the face and out of the large crack on the right, then finish up to the right end of a right-leaning rail. *Warning, as with Mt. Spickett Speeding Ticket, in the Fall, hiking up to the topout before you send this would be wise as the jug to topout can be full of pine needles, so clean them out before you.
content.location: Look for the little cave to the right, and slide on in.

content.description: Start with your left foot on the right starting hand hold of Cellah Dwellah and your right foot on a little lip, your right hand on an undercling, and your left hand on a sidepull in the start of the crack. Work up to the chockstone with help from a blocky crimp on the right, and pull up and over the slopers to top out.
content.location: It is to the right of Cellah Dwellah.

content.description:
This is a wall a few hundred feet east of the Roadside Cliff. The rock is all super hard and nothing like the granite that surrounds it. From far away (and in the pictures) the rock doesn't look great, but it's really accessible and worth a go. On the left side of the wall you will see "Mt. Spickett" written. 

  There is probably room to put in a couple harder lines on the faces, but what is included here are only the more obvious problems. (I named it this because it's literally written on the wall, but I definitely wasn't the first to climb it. So if there's already a name, let me know.)
